Award.AwardTitle: Broadening Geosciences Disciplines at the National Association of Black Geoscientists Annual Technical Conference: Houston, TX, September 5-8, 2018
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project provides partial support for about 10 faculty from historically black colleges and universities (HBCUs) and for about 50 students-of-color from across the nation to participate in the Annual Technical Conference of the National Association of Black Geoscientists (NABG), 5-8 September 2018 in Houston, TX. Engaging HBCU faculty in professional development opportunities such the NABG will help maintaining their scholarship and social capital among prospective employers of their graduates. Furthermore, most HBCU degree programs of relevance to the geosciences are environmental and atmospheric sciences programs. Students in these programs are historically under-represented at the NABG annual conference. The objective is to expand the disciplinary representation of NABG to include more people-of-color interested in broader disciplines of Geosciences. A primary aim of this project is to engage faculty and students in HBCU environmental sciences programs and aid their participation in a national conference of importance to placing them in the 21st Century geosciences workforce.

Despite the efforts of professional organizations like NABG, underrepresentation of African Americans in geosciences remains low. Recent assessments found that degree awards in geosciences to persons from underrepresented groups remain very low; <10% of geoscience degrees at every academic level are awarded to those with minority status, and African Americans earn fewer than 3% of geoscience baccalaureate degrees. Earlier participants in NABG meetings have continued in their academic preparation in geosciences or entered the national geosciences workforce; including 100% career advancement for students who attended at least four NABG conferences. Thus, participation of students-of-color in NABG appears to be strongly correlated with career success.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
NSF 1836331 provided financial support to students-of-color to participate in the 37th (2018) and 38th (2019) Annual Technical Conference of the National Association of Black Geoscientists. The conference is an opportunity for students to: 1) Participate in professional development workshops; 2) Interact with role models from a broad spectrum of experience levels within the geosciences; 3) Gain experience presenting results of research to professional audiences; 4) Expand their professional network and acquire social capital within the geosciences workforce; 5) Share experiences as people-of-color in a profession where they are underrepresented; 6) Advance awareness of NABG among students-of-color as a professional organization providing service to them; 7) Increase student participation in NABG through active membership in the organization. In 2018, NSF provided support for 67 student participants. Cost savings from the 37th NABG conference enabled support for an additional 65 student particpants at the 38th NABG conference in 2019. Thus, NSF 1836331 supported 132 participants at two national conferences. At the 37th conference (2018), students made oral presentations and poster presentations, participated in an 8-h pre-meeting professional development workshop sponsored by ExxonMobil, a 2-h seminar on networking and building social capital by the University of Arkansas, heard a keynote address from Dr. Stacy Lusk, Vice President for Information Systems and Technology for Kuwait Energy, the national energy company of Kuwait, participated in evening roundtable discussions of gender/race issues in the geoscience professions (men and women in seperate groups), and attended a professional development field trip focused on fluvial processes and fluvial sedimentology at Panther Creek County Park in the Woodlands, TX. At the 38th conference (2019), students made oral presentations and poster presentations, participated in an 8-h pre-meeting professional development workshop sponsored by ExxonMobil, a 2-h seminar on networking and building social capital presented by the Geological Society of America and the American Geophysical Union heard keynote addresses from NABG founding member Reginal Spiller (former Deputy Secretary of Energy and Fellow of the National Academy of Science) and Prof. Stephen Boss (University of Arkansas), participated in evening roundtable discussions of gender/race issues in the geoscience professions (men and women in seperate groups), and attended a professional development field trip focused on fluvial deposits of the Parthenon Sandstone (Pennsylvanian Period) in northwest Arkansas. All participants received significant professional
development opportunities and mentoring from geosciences professionals in
the private sector, public sector, and academia. Student participants are powerful advocates with their peers for NABG and share information about the organization across their social media accounts. As a consequence, many NABG attendees are connected by friendship to each other before and after conferences. This activity is growing a robust cohort of advancing geoscience professionals from a group profoundly underrepresented in the discipline. At least 34 former student participants in these conferences are now employed in the geoscience workforce in academia, government agencies, or the private sector. A number of these working professionals are in leadership in NABG and have taken active roles organizing the Annual Technical Conference and mentoring new generations of students.
